div.div:
We are still educating our students virtually and serving them meals via parking lot pick ups Mondays (6 meals) and Thursdays (4 meals + extra food) 10:30 a.m. - 12:30 p.m. at all 6 sites. The Middle and High School site is open every day for families that miss or cannot make one of the other days 6:00 a.m. - 6:00 p.m. Thank you to everyone who is helping with the meal program and to our community for all their support through this challenging time! #PinesPride
Read More >

span.a: You are currently on this page - Coronavirus (COVID-19) Updates

td.p: The Northland Pines School District values the health and well-being of our students, staff and families. We work throughout the year to promote healthy schools. Safety is always our priority. As the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) shares more information about COVID-19, we want you to know that we are regularly in contact with the Vilas County Health Department. Our school nurse and school health services staff work alongside school administrators to plan and respond to emerging communicable disease concerns following the guidance of the public health department and CDC recommendations.

p.strong:
The CDC always recommends everyday preventive actions to help
prevent the spread of respiratory viruses, including:
p.br:
• Wash your hands frequently with soap and water
• Help your students to wash their hands well
• Do not drop off your sick child at school
• Stay home when you're sick
• Cover your nose and mouth when coughing and sneezing
• Avoid close contact with anyone with cold or flu-like symptoms

p.strong: What is Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19)?

div.p: COVID-19 is a new disease that has not been previously seen in humans and that was first identified in Wuhan, China.

p.strong: What are common symptoms of COVID-19?

div.p:
The symptoms of COVID-19 may appear 2 – 14 days after contact with someone who has COVID-19:
• Fever
• Cough
• Shortness of breath

p.strong: How does COVID-19 spread?

div.p: The virus is found in droplets from a person’s throat or nose. COVID-19 is primarily spread when an infected person coughs or sneezes and other people breathe in those droplets. The virus also can spread when someone touches an object with the virus on it. If the person then touches his/her mouth, face or eyes, they can become infected.

p.em: The CDC offers the most up-to-date information concerning COVID-19.

p.strong: What are some good prevention strategies?

div.p:
Currently, there is no vaccine to prevent COVID-19 infection and no specific treatment. To help prevent the spread of respiratory viruses:
• Cover your coughs and sneezes with a sleeve or tissue
• Dispose of used tissues immediately and wash your hands
• Wash your hands with soap and water for 20 seconds especially before eating and after going to the bathroom, blowing your nose, coughing or sneezing
• When soap and water are not available, use hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol
• Avoid touching your eyes, nose and mouth
• Avoid close contact or shaking hands with people who are sick
• Remain at home when you are ill
• Clean and disinfect frequently touched objects and surfaces using a regular household cleaner or wipe

p.strong: Should I wear a mask?

div.p: At this time, the CDC notes that healthy people in the general population do not need to wear face masks. Masks may be appropriate for ill people in order to protect others from exposure. People with symptoms of respiratory illness (cough, fever) who visit health care providers will be asked to wear masks. Health care providers may recommend that some people with weakened immune systems wear masks in public.

p.strong: When should I keep my child home from school?

div.p:
Following are guidelines to help you make the best decision concerning whether your child should remain home.
• Fever: Keep a child home if they have a temperature of 100.5?F or higher. Remember a child must be fever free for 24 hours, without the use of medication, before returning to school.
• Strep throat: If your child has strep throat, they can return to school after 24 hours of antibiotic treatment or written approval from a doctor.
• Diarrhea: Children with loose stools should not be sent to school until they have been symptom-free for 24 hours.
• Vomiting: A child who is vomiting must be symptom-free for 24 hours before returning to school.
• Rash: Watch for rashes, especially those that cause a fever, itching or swelling.
• Chronic cough and/or green nose discharge: These conditions may be contagious and require treatment. Please visit your healthcare provider.
• Pink Eye: Eyes that have matted or crust on the eyelids after sleep, mucus or pus drainage, redness, and pain should be evaluated by a health care professional. Antibiotics should be used for 24 hours before returning to school.

p.strong:
What should I do if I have symptoms
(fever, cough, fatigue, shortness of breath?)

div.p:
• Contact your healthcare provider immediately
• Do not go to work or school
• Avoid contact with others

p.em: The CDC offers additional guidance concerning prevention strategies and the actions you should take if you think you or a family member may have COVID-19

p.strong: What steps is Northland Pines taking?

div.p:
• School buildings will be open to Northland Pines School District students ONLY from 7:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. until further notice. The late bus will no longer run.
• Effective midnight on Friday, March 13, 2020, and through April 5, 2020, all non-essential activities will be cancelled. This will include all school and community-based extra-curricular activities, after school events, activities, clubs, meetings, practices, performances and athletics.
• The Pines Community Wellness Center will be CLOSED TO THE PUBLIC effective Friday, March 13, 2020, and through April 5, 2020.
• SACC Beyond the Bell Childcare will remain open during regular scheduled hours. Parents will receive information about changes to pick up and drop off procedures.
• The Northland Pines School Board will hold a special meeting on Tuesday, March 17, 2020, at 9:30 a.m. in the Middle & High School Large Group Instruction Room to discuss pandemic planning, student and staff welfare, coronavirus, etc.
• If the School Board would make the decision or if we are forced to close, instruction will continue to be provided via virtual learning.

p.strong: Are school events canceled?

div.p: Yes, all school and community-based extra-curricular activities, after school events, activities, clubs, meetings, practices, performances and athletics are canceled. The School Board will be meeting on Tuesday for a Special Board Meeting regarding upcoming school-related trips.

p.strong: Are athletics and sports being suspended?

div.p: Yes, all after-school athletics and practices are canceled.

p.strong: Is the Pines Community Wellness Center still open to the public?

div.p: No, the Pines Community Wellness Center will be CLOSED TO THE PUBLIC effective Friday, March 13, 2020, and through April 5, 2020.

p.strong: Will SACC Beyond the Bell Childcare be open?

div.p: Yes, SACC Beyond the Bell Childcare will remain open during regular scheduled hours. Parents will receive information about changes to pick up and drop off procedures.

p.strong: Are school facilities available in the evening?

div.p: No, school buildings will be open to Northland Pines School District students ONLY from 7:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. until further notice.

p.strong: Will Northland Pines continue to feed students during this time?

div.p:
Yes, we are offering an Extended Closure Meal Program.
• Meals are FREE
• Include one breakfast and one lunch per child
• Meals are available to ANY child ages 0-18
• You do NOT have to attend NPSD to receive meals
Parking lot pick up at Land O' Lakes Elementary, St. Germain Elementary, Northland Pines Middle & High School, Conover Evangelical Free Church, the Sayner Public Library & the Dome.
We ask that you call 715-479-6471 to register.

td.p: The COVID-19 situation is constantly evolving and changing. We understand there is uncertainly involved in this situation. We plan to keep you informed as needed. We encourage you to contact Caryn Jacob, NPSD School Nurse, or the local public health department if you have further questions.

p.br:
To ensure you receive the most timely information from us, please be certain the contact information for your family is current in Campus.
• Campus Parent
• Campus Help Center
